Award.AwardTitle: Demand-Response PEV Charging Control in Smart Grids for Renewable Supply Utilization and Hedging and Transfer of Forecast Risk

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
There are currently two major developments shaping the electricity market. On the supply side, there is increasing push towards the use of renewable energy sources, which are however associated with a highly variable rate of energy supply. On the demand side, there is increasing deployment of plug-in (hybrid) electric vehicles (PEVs/PHEVs), which will not only increase the average electricity consumption significantly, but also generate very bursty demand patterns. Fortunately, PEVs also provide significant flexibility in terms of their energy consumption rates and schedules, and we believe that variability in the supply side can be partly "absorbed" using the flexibility. This constitutes the broad goal of this project, which aims at efficient PEV demand scheduling mechanisms for effective utilization of variable-rate renewable energy sources, and hedging of forecast risks by electric utilities (aggregators). These mechanisms would allow the partial transfer of risk associated with variability of energy generation/supply -- from the electricity suppliers and aggregators (and in turn the generators) to the consumers (PEV users), in exchange of a reduced price of charging. The solutions resulting from this project for the PEV charging context would also be applicable to other elastic loads that are associated with a partly predictable amount of energy consumption over a time span. The issues considered in this project are critical for the stability and profitable operation of the electric grid as it copes up with the increased deployments of PEVs, and attempts to integrate renewable energy generation at a large scale.

More specifically, this project investigates two demand-response control strategies for charging PEVs in the smart grid. In the first method, the utility (or aggregator) sets time- and location-dependent prices for PEV charging, while letting the PEVs (or the smart meters associated with PEV charging) mostly do the scheduling, based on the individual best interests and constraints of the PEV owners. In the second method, the utility offers (in the market) hard and soft contracts to charge PEVs up to certain levels within a specified interval, which the PEVs purchase based on their needs and preferences; the scheduling of the PEV charging is then done by the utility itself such that adheres to the terms of the contracts that it has sold to the PEVs. Two broad inter-related research issues will be explored in this context. The first involves the design of these contracts, as well as the associated "contract portfolio optimization" question - which involves deciding on the how many hard and soft contracts the utility should offer to attain its desired risk-return tradeoff point. The second involves the process of offering these contracts through auctions and other market clearing mechanisms that are "incentive-compatible" (i.e., invoke truthful response from the PEVs), and result in overall "social efficiency" of the resulting energy allocation. Predictive, demand-response control within these two pricing/scheduling frameworks for PEV charging brings about challenging issues that can be modeled using tools and techniques in stochastic game theory, auction mechanism design, stochastic calculus, and risk management, but must be suitably adapted and extended to consider the models, constraints and requirements of the PEV charging and renewable energy supply processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of this project include new pricing mechanisms and scheduling algorithms for charging of plug-in electric vehicles (PEVs) that can result in more efficient grid operation. The three key outcomes that are directly related to the project goals are as follows.

Firstly, the project resulted in new time-dependent pricing policies for PEV charging. The optimal time-dependent pricing schemes ? that would result in minimizing the variance of the load in the distribution grid over time ? were characterized for both the cases of day-ahead and real-time pricing. In the day-ahead pricing case, the pricing structure was determined based on statistical distribution of observed user (PEV owner) preferences, whereas the real-time pricing strategy required dynamic (stochastic) optimization. Comparison of the two pricing schemes showed that real-time pricing does to provide much advantage over time-ahead pricing ? in terms of overall reduction in the peak load in the grid ? if the charging constraints/preferences are well estimated. Extension of these pricing strategies to take into account distribution feeder constraints was also considered.

Secondly, the project resulted in new auction mechanisms that can attain economic efficiency in the grid while incentivizing users (PEV owners) to declare their charging preferences truthfully. An extension of a progressive second price (PSP) auction, called elastic-supply PSP (es-PSP) was developed, that required users to provide simple two-dimensional bid: the amount of energy it wants to obtain and the per-unit price it is willing to pay for the energy desired. The resulting equilibria were shown to be socially efficient. It was further shown that in this auction mechanism, a user acting in self-interest does not have any incentive for untruthfully declaring its willingness-to-pay value for the quantity of energy it wishes to obtain.

Thirdly, the project developed a pricing strategy that approximately maximizes the seller?s profit without compromising on the overall system utility. In general, maximizing social efficiency in PEV charging can result in a solution that yields poor revenue for the aggregator (seller) that serves the PEV load. Likewise, a solution that maximizes aggregator revenue (which is also hard to compute in general) can result in poor social utility. The solution developed in this project can simultaneously achieve profit and social utility that is within a small constant factor of their respective optima, and the solution can be computed in an efficient manner. Simulations support the theoretical results by showing that in practice, the algorithm?s performance tends to be very good, and even better than the theoretical guarantees. These solutions may therefore be satisfactory to both the grid operators and the aggregators.

In addition to these core outcomes on demand-response mechanism for PEV charging, the project has also resulted in effective demand-response mechanisms utilizing thermostatic loads. The project has shown how the flexibility associated with typical building thermostatic loads can be utilized to shave off significant cost during hours of peak power usage in the smart grid. As another side investigation, the project has also explored how risk exposure of renewable energy companies can be reduced, making them more profitable. The outcomes from this aspect of the project include the design of novel renewable energy service contracts, which can help better use of renewable energy sources for serving flexible demand such as PEV loads. 

This project has led to several publications in international journals and conferences, and has contributed to one PhD dissertation. The pricing and auction mechanism designed and analyzed in this project provide strong insights on how PEV charging should be done so that the harmful effect of this additional load on the grid is minimized, while keeping PEV charging economically viable. Further, the project has also shown how these demand-response mechanisms developed for PEV charging can be extended to other flexible demands like thermostatic loads. These demand response mechanism can reduce the stress on the grid, and help in better utilization of variable supply renewable energy sources.
